thread.title: Cassel no quick fix for Cowboys' woes
thread.title_full: Cassel no quick fix for Cowboys' woes

author: Eric Prisbell, USA TODAY Sports
title: Cassel no quick fix for Cowboys' woes
text:
Cassel no quick fix for Cowboys' woes USA Today Sports 8 hrs ago by Eric Prisbell, USA TODAY Sports © Mike Stone, Getty Images Mike Stone, Getty Images After losing their third game in a row, the Dallas Cowboys are making a change at quarterback, though that won’t necessarily solve the myriad issues plaguing an offense that has sorely missed its two biggest stars.
Veteran Matt Cassel, who was acquired in a late-September trade with the Buffalo Bills, has been informed he will start in place of Brandon Weeden when the Cowboys play again in an important NFC East game at the New York Giants on Oct. 25.
AdChoices The change is not unexpected.
VIDEO: Cowboys will bench Brandon Weeden and start Matt Cassel
Cowboys coach Jason Garrett said he would evaluate the quarterback position during this bye week on the heels of a 30-6 loss to the New England Patriots. Weeden has lost all three starts in place of Tony Romo and 11 consecutive NFL starts.
Dallas Cowboys Passing Performance Per Game in 2015 | PointAfter
Without Romo (broken collarbone) or the deep-threat potential from wide receiver Dez Bryant, who's expected to return in the coming weeks from a broken right foot, the running game has struggled mightily, especially on first down. Neither Joseph Randle nor Darren McFadden has successfully filled the void left by DeMarco Murray, last year’s NFL rushing leader who departed for the Philadelphia Eagles. Christine Michael has had limited opportunities, as well.
What’s more, the team is devoid of consistent playmakers in the passing game, especially when teams double cover tight end Jason Witten. The loss of versatile running back/pass catcher Lance Dunbar, who tore his anterior cruciate ligament in an overtime loss against the New Orleans Saints, was significant.
As for receivers, Terrance Williams has struggled to fill the shoes of Bryant as the top receiver. Garrett said, overall, the receivers have struggled at times to win individual battles.
Cassel, who served as Weeden’s backup against the Patriots, is more accomplished than Weeden, having led the Patriots to 10 wins after Tom Brady was lost for the season in 2008. Cassel also led the Kansas City Chiefs to the AFC West title in 2010.
But the offensive issues clearly run deeper than one position in Dallas. And the team is unlikely to see a significant boost offensively until Romo and Bryant return.
As owner Jerry Jones wondered after the loss to the Patriots: Will it be too late by that point? The team badly needs a few victories before Romo can return Nov. 22. They had no choice but to turn to Cassel.
Follow Eric Prisbell on Twitter @EricPrisbell .
